title: If set A is a subset of B and B is a subset of C, then which is the bigger set? - Quora

response.answer_text: If A is a subset of B, it is still possible for the set A to be the same as the set B, so it is quite possible that all three sets in this question (A, B, and C) are identical — in which case, none of them are “bigger” than the others. However, if A is a “proper subset” of B then A is “smaller” than B (because A will contain some elements that are not elements of B). if we re-word the question, inserting “proper” in front of the word “subset”, then the question would read: “If set A is a proper subset of B and B is a proper subset of C, then which is the bigger set?” and the answer is “C”. Note also that infinite sets have somewhat different behavior, and the term “bigger” cannot be used to compare the “size” of infinite sets (such as the number of even number or the number of primes). However, I’m assuming that the question assumed finite sets. I might add that radical notions such as the above (i.e about sets that could be proper subsets of themselves) once got a post-graduate math student kicked out of school by his professor. That student, Georg Cantor, is now well known for his works on infinities, but nobody remembers the Prof.

Since you have claimed that they are subsets, I'll be assuming that there is no possibility of them being proper subsets. In this case, C would be the biggest set as it has the most elements in it. Followed by B then A. n(A) <= n(B) <= n(C) Edit: Thanks Graeme Foster for pointing out the error:)
